text: Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: I, I don’t know enough about either drug in terms of the side effect profile. I, I know the one where you get one or the other has been pretty well tolerated. Uh, and the other drug is, uh, I haven’t put anybody on the trial yet, so I don’t have the experience, but, uh, I know from our meetings, I haven’t heard any signal that says this is horribly toxic. So, uh, so I, I think side effect wise, I don’t think that we’re going to have that much problem. It’s really just a matter of can we-? Family Member: So they saw a lot of more spots on his bone from the last, uh-? Doctor: Yeah. Let me, uh, pull that up. So- (pause14sec) Patient: Um hum. (Laughter) Doctor: Uh, right. (Sound Door closes) Family Member: It’s too bad they haven’t came up with something more with the bones whereas they can, you know? Doctor: Well. Family Member: Interact with- Doctor: There’s been a lot of- (Sound Door opens) Family Member: Oh, no. Doctor: Spine and ribs and shoulders. Family Member: Spine, ribs, and shoulder? (pause11sec)

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Then you and I just have to pick a day when you wanna start chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, some of it is, you can look at a calendar. The end of the year is coming. You know, Christmas, New Year’s, Thanksgiving. You know, what day, eh, do you wanna plan it out. ‘Cuz once we get started, it’s gonna be every three weeks. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay? You’re gonna come in two weeks which would be the twenty-first. You could theoretically get your first chemo then. You may also say, “Uh, no, let’s wait two more weeks.” Patient: Until the third of January or something. Doctor: You could wait until the third of January, or you could -- Patient: Now, if you got - You, you – I grabbed that number out of the air. You can – Doctor: You could try to wait or things like that. Healthcare Professional: Yeah, he could wait. Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Because, again, I like to wait a little bit. Patient: After the, uh, hormones?

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: That sort of again goes more with arthritis. Okay. Family Member: Okay so if he doesn’t want to do surgery what about laser surgery? I mean that’s not opening it up. Is that another… Doctor: Right yeah that is absolutely an option. Family Member: …viable option? Doctor: And I would ask the neurosurgeon about it. Frankly if laser is an option for this location, for that… Family Member: Right. Doctor: Exact lesion things like that because I really don’t know exactly which lesions would be good for that. Definitely ask about there is a procedure called kyphoplasty which can stabilize the spine. Patient: Hypo? Doctor: Kypho, kypho. K-Y-P-H-O and you know that’s something also to uh explore with neurosurgery. Okay? So um… Patient: Yeah I I’m not too anxious to have them go in there if it’s not gonna help me. text: Patient: If it does not work. But, at the same time, I think you have to give the, uh, the drug the opportunity – to work. Doctor: Right. Patient: And that’s why initially when we started, and, uh, and L___, she said, well, Mr. S___, you have the clinical trial. And I believe we’ve, we’ve had, we took the clinical trial. I knew that the doses that I was going to have was, was in a low dosage, and I know it’s going to have some effect there. So my thing is, D___, deal with it as long as you can. So I did. We lowered it down. I have felt changes. I used to have pain, uh, running down this area. I mean serious pain. My back, wherever I used to have pain here, and, uh, I don’t have it anymore. Now, yes, she does rub me down every night. I take two hot, uh, uh, baths each day. Sometimes in the morning, sometimes at night. Uh, I take those hot baths because when I stiffen up or, and, uh, I kind of said, okay, I need to get in the tub. I put some Epsom salt sitting in, and I sit in the tub about fifteen minutes, and then I get back out. And I said, okay, I can deal with another day. So, again, from my perspective, is that I wanted to see the drug do what it needs to do. I don’t know what the window is. I’m not a medical professional, whatever, so I don’t know that. But I do know that I have seen, uh, uh, changes taking place. I do know that even now I could go and walk around this block. Uh, I shouldn’t, but I probably could. So, uh, the sleeping part, the OxyContin sometimes works, uh, when I take it and I go to sleep. But during the daytime while you’re at work, I normally, I can’t do what I used to do, but I can get along pretty good. We’re talking about at night. We’re talking about at night. And I’m trying to get comfortable in the bed. I wish I could sleep on my stomach but I haven’t figured out a way of, uh, sleeping back on my stomach like I used to. Uh, I just don’t feel comfortable when I sleep on my stomach. So, I’m not, uh, disagreeing with what you said your observations are, uh, but, I’m trying to work with the, with the prescription that we’re taking already. And I didn’t think it was going to be easy. If it was going to be easy, uh, this drug probably would have been FDA approved a long time ago, if it was going to be easy. You know? It may not work. But, again, you never know. We were off of it for, uh, I think three weeks. Family Member: Three weeks. Patient: Three weeks. And then I got a call from two doctors. I don’t even remember where their office is. And they said that, uh, my cancer had stabilized. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: But they didn’t explain to me what that meant. So what do you mean, stabilized? Does that mean that it’s not growing? Does it mean that it’s not, uh, progressing? Does it mean it’s not going the other way? What, what do you mean, stabilized? Doctor: Yeah. I think that meant that the, the CT and bone scan from August first and August second did not look any, any worse than the ones before that. They also didn’t look any better but the cancer had stopped growing and spreading further. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So that what, you know, stabilizing means. So I’ve heard everything that you had to say. And it, it seems very clear that you’re leaning towards continuing on the study and I think that’s a reasonable idea. There has been nothing so far on this study that is an absolute reason to stop. An absolute reason to stop would be, for example, if your scans showed unequivocal progression of the cancer. That would be one reason. Another reason would be if your pain was getting so bad that we had to consider radiation to the bone to eliminate the pain. Uh, another would be if you had any, uh, very serious side effect to the medication that is not reversible. Uh, so, what I think we should do is this. It sounds like you want to try to give this a bit more time. I think that about two months from now, roughly, a bit less, because your scans were on August first and second, so, roughly, I think the first week of October, you’re going to be getting another CT scan and another bone scan, because this trial requires the scan every eight weeks. Uh, let’s try to keep you on the study until that point in time because that’s going to give us a lot more information about, you know, comparing that scan to the previous one and then comparing that scan to the very, very first one, your baseline, as we call it. Uh, plus by then, we’re going to have two more PSAs. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: To see if that’s stabilizing at all. And we’re going to know also from you how you’re feeling in terms of your bone pain. Like, is it overall getting slightly worse over time or if that’s stabilized, or is it perhaps improving?

text: Healthcare Professional: Oh, I’m so sorry. Doctor: Not blood? Patient: Not blood, no. That's all I know about it. I mean, I just know that it’s not a good thing. Healthcare Professional: Do you have a feeling about it? Do you have a preference? Would you prefer to stay on the blood thinner? Patient: I just think- I just renewed it. Healthcare Professional: Oh. Patient: So I think I'll stay the course and then we'll see what happens after that. Because I'm pretty good watching. If anything is swelling or if I’m having any pain. I'll be a little more vigilant now to go to the doctor whereas before I'm like. Doctor: Hopefully it doesn’t happen while you’re on the medicine. Patient: Right, no, I'm saying if I got off of it, I'd be a little more vigilant about the idea that if I have swelling, I should go to the doctor because it might not just be me being a macho jock, but I have a problem. Doctor: And so what I hear you say- is that you just got a prescription and how long is that going to be for? Patient: I think that's for three more months. Doctor: So that would be your plan to sort of go and then stop for six months. Healthcare Professional: Okay

text: Patient: Okay, so let me ask you a question. So what is the next thing to do? Doctor: Yeah, so that; we have talked about that. You know your kidney function has gotten better. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You know so that is one of the key parts about you being eligible, that if your kidney function was too high, makes it difficult for us to use chemotherapy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Chemotherapy with your numbers today, you could certainly go ahead and start moving forward with that and picking a date. You know for you to do the clinical trial then we do have to have you; D___ even kept an eye on you and let me know that you were in the hospital. You know we’ve got all kinds of I think Dr._____ one note said that Family Member: No, we’ve been communicating by email. So we were in Doctor: And you definitely needed to be in the hospital then going closer to home is the right thing. And basically all they needed was to put a catheter in and then that was putting pressure off of your kidney. Patient: Yeah. Right. Doctor: And you know we’ve got our fingers crossed that the hormones are going to be it and adding chemo to the clinical trial would be you know a step above that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The issue for the radiation you know is – one of the things is do we just watch. You know hormones to Dr. ____ that should be enough. Chemo is also going to try to kill cancer cells. Patient: Uh hum.

text: Patient: Is that just starting? Doctor: Uh, that has been open probably for a couple of months. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But it has a lot of rules. Either, you have to be AR-V7 positive. So, we would have to draw a tube of blood. Uh, and that we can do. Uh, it takes a week to come back. If you scream positive with that as positive, then the team could talk to you about the study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. If you’re negative, then you’re not eligible from the get-go. Patient: Right. Doctor: Because you have to be positive to go onto that study. The other two studies, it doesn’t matter about what your AR-V7. AR-V7 gives us a sense of what’s the likelihood that Enzalutamide’s gonna work. Patient: Okay. Doctor: What’s the likelihood that Abiraterone’s gonna work. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Um. In this case, we’re trying to just sort out men who, um, have an AR-V7 positive as a bad thing. Uh. So, that says that we’re willing to go with immune therapy which hasn’t been proven at a high risk/high gain, uh, thing in that kind of individual.

text: Patient: But where do you draw the line as to how much you can take, you know? Well - Doctor: I don’t know. Well, that’s the problem. Patient: It didn’t affect me Doctor: Safety-wise, right now it’s only six months, you know. And there are some unexpected effects that are coming out for radium with um Zytiga because people have had, well there’s no problems with just adding the radium- Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: on top of the Zytiga. Now two/three years later, the study that they did of the combination is reporting way more factures and issues. Family Member: OOH! Doctor: So those were surprising Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: effects that nobody expected. Patient: Am I going to be sterile now? Family Member: Oh Jesus! (chuckle) Doctor: No, there’s no reason for you to. Not from the chemo.
conv1077_1-snip11.displayed_text: Patient: But where do you draw the line as to how much you can take, you know? Well - Doctor: I don’t know. Well, that’s the problem. Patient: It didn’t affect me Doctor: Safety-wise, right now it’s only six months, you know. And there are some unexpected effects that are coming out for radium with um Zytiga because people have had, well there’s no problems with just adding the radium- Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: on top of the Zytiga. Now two/three years later, the study that they did of the combination is reporting way more factures and issues. Family Member: OOH! Doctor: So those were surprising Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: effects that nobody expected. Patient: Am I going to be sterile now? Family Member: Oh Jesus! (chuckle) Doctor: No, there’s no reason for you to. Not from the chemo.

text: Family Member: Right. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So I’m fine with it. We fuss over big joints, hips, legs… Patient: Okay. Doctor: Shoulders because they can crack. Family Member: We were thinking it was right and not left. Patient: Yeah something to do with the hip replacement thought too. Doctor: Well the hip replacement always glows so then we always look for the other side to make sure that you don’t have a matching set. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: So the issue is if you start to feel it because you’re working more, or you’re lounging more, or doing whatever more up north and you’re aware, but it’s more of an awareness thing not we’re about to do this. Patient: Um hum, um hum. Doctor: People know and this is kind of like you know your right hip wasn’t functioning well before.

text: Family Member: Okay. Alright. I didn’t mean not to take it home- Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: -but I meant if questions come up we could ask them. Doctor: Oh I see what you mean. Family Member: Let’s read it through in here and see if we have questions. I’m not asking you to sign it. Doctor: Yeah. Okay and then that way you – you know I’ll check back with you if you have questions. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: That’s a good idea. Just write them down though that way… Family Member: We’re not taking up a room? You want us to go back in the lobby? Doctor: If they need you to go to the lobby we’ll let you know. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Alright and did I – yeah you got your copy of – well this is your CAT scan and a copy too.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
